verses.text: This is the word of the LORD that came to Jeremiah concerning the drought:
verses.comment: The context is a specific drought sent as judgment. The prophet often acts as God's mouthpiece during times of crisis.

verses.text: Judah mourns, her gates languish; her people sit on the ground in mourning, and the cry of Jerusalem goes up.
verses.comment: The gates symbolize leadership and security. Mourning here indicates both physical and spiritual dryness.

verses.text: Their nobles send their servants for water; they come to the cisterns, but find no water. They return with their vessels empty. They are ashamed and confounded and cover their heads.
verses.comment: Empty vessels are a metaphor for spiritual emptiness. The shame reflects public humiliation due to God's judgment.

verses.text: Because the ground is cracked, for there has been no rain in the land, the farmers are ashamed; they cover their heads.
verses.comment: Drought is often a consequence of covenant unfaithfulness (Deut. 28:23-24).

verses.text: Even the doe in the field abandons her newborn because there is no grass.
verses.comment: Creation itself groans under human sin (Rom. 8:22), here animals suffer from human rebellion.

verses.text: The wild donkeys stand on the barren heights; they pant for air like jackals. Their eyes fail because there is no vegetation.
verses.comment: God's judgment is shown not just on people, but the whole created order (compare Gen. 3:17–18).

verses.text: Though our iniquities testify against us, LORD, act for your name’s sake! For our backslidings are many; we have sinned against you.
verses.comment: A humble confession. Not for their own sake, but for the Lord’s name—hint of mediation on behalf of the people.

verses.text: O Hope of Israel, its Savior in times of distress, why are you like a stranger in the land, like a traveler who stays but for a night?
verses.comment: The Lord is acknowledged as Israel’s only Savior (cf. Isa. 43:11). The sense of abandonment is strong, prefiguring the longing for ultimate redemption.

verses.text: Why are you like a man taken by surprise, like a mighty warrior who cannot save? Yet you, LORD, are in our midst, and we are called by your name; do not forsake us!
verses.comment: Despite their failures, the Lord remains present—a foreshadowing of God-with-us (Immanuel, Isa. 7:14; Matt. 1:23).

verses.text: This is what the LORD says concerning this people: 'They love to wander; they do not restrain their feet. So the LORD does not accept them; now he will remember their iniquity and punish their sins.'
verses.comment: Judgment comes after persistent rejection of God’s guidance. See also Hos. 8:13.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to me, 'Do not pray for the welfare of this people.'
verses.comment: Intercessory prayer is set aside—focusing on the seriousness of their sin and the need for true repentance from the people.

verses.text: Even if they fast, I will not listen to their cry; even if they offer burnt offerings and grain offerings, I will not accept them. Instead, I will consume them by sword, famine, and plague.
verses.comment: Rituals alone do not bring favor when hearts have turned away—a warning also echoed in Isa. 1:11–15 and Amos 5:22.

verses.text: But I said, 'Ah, Lord GOD! The prophets are saying to them,

verses: You will not see the sword or famine, but I will give you true peace in this place.
